title: Lab Compute Guide
text:
Welcome
This guide teaches you how to perform computational analysis using a modern, reproducible workflow. You’ll learn to use:

title: Lab Compute Guide
text:
Who This Guide Is For
This guide is written for students and researchers who have some programming experience but want to learn professional workflows for computational analysis. You should be comfortable with basic R or Python syntax, but don’t need prior experience with the specific tools covered here.

title: Lab Compute Guide
text:
How to Use This Guide
If you’re new, start with Part 1: Quick Start. You’ll install all the tools and create your first project in about 30 minutes.
If you need a reference, jump to Part 2: Core Tools for detailed coverage of each tool.
If you’re looking for workflows, see Part 3: Workflows for task-oriented guides.

title: Lab Compute Guide
text:
The Philosophy
We emphasize:

Reproducibility — Your analyses should run on any machine
Version control — Track changes and collaborate effectively
Environment isolation — Each project has its own dependencies
AI assistance — Use modern tools to accelerate your work

Let’s get started.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 Why These Tools?
Modern computational analysis requires more than just writing code. You need to:
The tools in this guide work together to solve these challenges:

title: 1  Introduction
text:
Reproduce your results — Run the same analysis months later and get the same output
Collaborate effectively — Share code with colleagues without “it works on my machine” problems
Manage complexity — Keep track of dependencies, data, and analysis steps
Work efficiently — Leverage modern tools to speed up your workflow





Tool
Purpose




Positron
IDE designed for data science (R + Python)


Conda
Python environment management


renv
R package management


Git/GitHub
Version control and collaboration


Claude Code
AI-assisted coding and analysis

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.2 How They Fit Together
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                   Positron                       │
│              (Your workspace)                    │
│                                                  │
│  ┌──────────┐  ┌──────────┐  ┌──────────────┐  │
│  │  Conda   │  │   renv   │  │  Claude Code │  │
│  │ (Python) │  │   (R)    │  │    (AI)      │  │
│  └──────────┘  └──────────┘  └──────────────┘  │
│                                                  │
│  ┌──────────────────────────────────────────┐   │
│  │              Git / GitHub                 │   │
│  │        (Version control for all)          │   │
│  └──────────────────────────────────────────┘   │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
Positron is your central workspace where you write and run code. It integrates with all the other tools.
Conda manages Python environments — isolated spaces with specific Python versions and packages for each project.
renv does the same for R — tracking which R packages each project needs.
Git tracks changes to your code over time. GitHub hosts your code online for backup and collaboration.
Claude Code is an AI assistant that runs in your terminal and helps you write, debug, and understand code.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.3 What You’ll Learn
By the end of Part 1, you will have:

All tools installed and configured
Created a project with both R and Python code
Tracked it with Git and pushed to GitHub
Used Claude Code to help write code

Let’s start by installing everything.

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.1 1. Positron
This chapter walks you through installing all the tools you need. Follow the sections in order.
Positron is a data science IDE built on VS Code, designed specifically for R and Python work.

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.1.1 macOS

Download Positron from https://positron.posit.co
Open the .dmg file and drag Positron to your Applications folder
Open Positron from Applications



2.1.2 Windows

Download Positron from https://positron.posit.co
Run the installer (.exe file)
Follow the installation prompts
Launch Positron from the Start menu







TipFirst Launch



When you first open Positron, it may ask to install recommended extensions. Accept these defaults.

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.2 2. Conda (Miniforge)
We use Miniforge, a minimal conda installer that defaults to the conda-forge channel.

2.2.1 macOS
Open Terminal and run:
# Download the installer
curl -L -O "https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-MacOSX-$(uname -m).sh"

# Run the installer
bash Miniforge3-MacOSX-$(uname -m).sh
Follow the prompts, accepting the defaults. When asked about initializing conda, say yes.
After installation, restart your terminal or run:
source ~/.zshrc
Verify the installation:
conda --version


2.2.2 Windows

Download the Miniforge installer from https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases

Choose Miniforge3-Windows-x86_64.exe

Run the installer
Check “Add Miniforge3 to my PATH environment variable” during installation
Complete the installation

Open a new PowerShell or Command Prompt and verify:
conda --version

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.3 3. R (using rig)
We use rig (R Installation Manager) to install and manage R versions. This makes it easy to install R, switch between versions, and keep R updated.

2.3.1 macOS
First, install rig using Homebrew:
brew tap r-lib/rig
brew install --cask rig
Then install the latest R version:
rig add release
Verify the installation:
R --version






Tiprig Commands




rig list — See installed R versions
rig add release — Install latest stable R
rig add devel — Install development version
rig default <version> — Set default R version





2.3.2 Windows

Download the rig installer from https://github.com/r-lib/rig/releases

Choose rig-windows-latest.exe

Run the installer
Open a new PowerShell window and install R:

rig add release

Verify:

R --version


2.3.3 Why rig?

Easy updates: rig add release always gets the latest version
Multiple versions: Install R 4.3 and R 4.4 side by side for testing
Clean uninstall: rig rm <version> removes R cleanly
Consistent: Same commands on macOS and Windows

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.4 4. Git

2.4.1 macOS
Git may already be installed. Check by running:
git --version
If not installed, you’ll be prompted to install the Xcode Command Line Tools. Accept the prompt.
Alternatively, install via Homebrew:
brew install git


2.4.2 Windows

Download Git from https://git-scm.com/download/win
Run the installer
Accept the default options (the defaults are good)
Verify in a new terminal:

git --version


2.4.3 Configure Git (Both Platforms)
Set your identity (use your real name and email):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.5 5. GitHub Account

Go to https://github.com and create an account if you don’t have one
We’ll set up authentication in Section 3.9

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.6 6. Claude Code
Claude Code is an AI coding assistant that runs in your terminal.

2.6.1 Prerequisites
You need Node.js 18+ installed:
macOS:
brew install node
Windows: Download and install from https://nodejs.org (LTS version).


2.6.2 Install Claude Code
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code


2.6.3 Authenticate
Run Claude Code once to authenticate:
claude
Follow the prompts to log in with your Anthropic account.






NoteAnthropic Account



You’ll need an Anthropic account with API access. If you’re a lab member, ask for credentials.

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.7 7. Quarto (Optional)
Quarto is useful for creating reports and documents. This book was built with Quarto.

2.7.1 macOS
brew install quarto
Or download from https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/


2.7.2 Windows
Download and run the installer from https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.8 Verification Checklist
Run these commands to verify everything is installed:
# Check each tool
positron --version  # Or just open Positron
conda --version
R --version
git --version
claude --version
quarto --version    # If installed
All commands should return version numbers without errors.






TipTroubleshooting



If any command fails with “command not found”:

macOS: Try opening a new terminal window
Windows: Try opening a new PowerShell window
Check that the tool’s install directory is in your PATH

See Troubleshooting for common issues.

title: 2  Installation
text:
2.9 Next Steps
Now that everything is installed, let’s create your first project.

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.1 Step 1: Create the Project Folder
Let’s create a complete project that uses all the tools together. By the end, you’ll have:
Open your terminal and create a new project:

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
# Navigate to where you keep projects
cd ~/Documents  # or wherever you prefer

# Create and enter the project folder
mkdir my-first-analysis
cd my-first-analysis

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.2 Step 2: Open in Positron
Open Positron and use File → Open Folder to open my-first-analysis.
[TODO: screenshot of Positron with empty folder open]

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.3 Step 3: Initialize Git
In Positron’s terminal (View → Terminal), initialize a Git repository:
git init
Create a .gitignore file to exclude files that shouldn’t be tracked:
# Create .gitignore
cat > .gitignore << 'EOF'
# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/
renv/library/
renv/staging/

# Python
__pycache__/
*.pyc
.conda/
.venv/

# Data (large files)
data/raw/

# OS files
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db

# IDE
.vscode/
.positron/
EOF

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.4 Step 4: Set Up Conda Environment
Create a conda environment for this project:
conda create -n my-first-analysis python=3.11 -y
conda activate my-first-analysis
Install some basic packages:
conda install pandas numpy matplotlib -y
Save the environment specification:
conda env export > environment.yml






TipEnvironment Activation



Every time you work on this project, activate the environment first:
conda activate my-first-analysis

title: 3  Your First Project
section: 3.5 Step 5: Set Up R with renv
text:
3.5 Step 5: Set Up R with renv
In Positron’s R console (or terminal running R), initialize renv:
# Install renv if needed
install.packages("renv")

# Initialize renv for this project
renv::init()
This creates: - renv/ folder for package library - renv.lock file tracking package versions - .Rprofile to auto-activate renv
Install a package to test:
install.packages("ggplot2")
renv::snapshot()  # Save the state

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.6 Step 6: Create Project Structure
Create a standard folder structure:
mkdir -p data/raw data/processed scripts output
Your project now looks like:
my-first-analysis/
├── .git/
├── .gitignore
├── data/
│   ├── raw/          # Original data (not tracked)
│   └── processed/    # Cleaned data
├── scripts/          # Analysis scripts
├── output/           # Results, figures
├── environment.yml   # Conda environment
├── renv/             # R packages
└── renv.lock         # R package versions

title: 3  Your First Project
section: 3.7 Step 7: Write Code with Claude Code
text:
3.7 Step 7: Write Code with Claude Code
Now let’s use Claude Code to help write some analysis code.
In the terminal, start Claude Code:
claude
Try asking it to create a simple analysis script:

“Create a Python script in scripts/ that loads a CSV file, calculates summary statistics, and saves a plot”

Claude Code will: 1. Ask clarifying questions if needed 2. Write the code for you 3. Save it to the file
[TODO: screenshot of Claude Code interaction]
Do the same for R:

“Create an R script in scripts/ that does similar analysis using tidyverse and ggplot2”

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.8 Step 8: Make Your First Commit
Stage and commit your work:
# See what files are ready to commit
git status

# Add all files (except those in .gitignore)
git add .

# Make your first commit
git commit -m "Initial project setup with conda and renv"

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.9 Step 9: Push to GitHub

3.9.1 Create a GitHub Repository

Go to github.com and click New repository
Name it my-first-analysis
Keep it private (or public if you prefer)
Don’t initialize with README (we already have files)
Click Create repository



3.9.2 Authenticate with GitHub
The easiest method is using the GitHub CLI:
# Install GitHub CLI
# macOS:
brew install gh

# Windows: Download from https://cli.github.com/

# Authenticate
gh auth login
Follow the prompts to authenticate via browser.


3.9.3 Push Your Code
# Add the remote repository
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/my-first-analysis.git

# Push your code
git push -u origin main

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.10 Congratulations!
You’ve created a complete project with:

✅ Organized folder structure
✅ Python environment (conda)
✅ R package management (renv)
✅ Version control (Git)
✅ Cloud backup (GitHub)
✅ AI-assisted code (Claude Code)

title: 3  Your First Project
text:
3.11 What’s Next?

Part 2 dives deeper into each tool
Part 3 covers common workflows like collaboration and reproducibility

When you return to this project later:
cd my-first-analysis
conda activate my-first-analysis
# R will auto-activate renv when you start it
positron .  # Or open Positron and navigate to the folder

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.1 Why Positron?
Positron is a data science IDE built by Posit (formerly RStudio) on top of VS Code. It combines the power of VS Code with native support for R and Python data science workflows.
[TODO: screenshot of Positron interface with labeled panes]

title: 4  Positron
text:
Dual language support: First-class support for both R and Python
Data viewer: Inspect dataframes and tibbles interactively
Variable explorer: See all objects in your environment
Integrated terminal: Run shell commands without leaving the IDE
Extensions: Access the VS Code extension ecosystem

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.2 Key Interface Elements

4.2.1 The Console
The console at the bottom shows your R or Python session. You can:

Run code interactively
See output and errors
Switch between R and Python sessions



4.2.2 The Environment Pane
Shows all variables in your current session:

Dataframes with row/column counts
Click to view data in the Data Viewer
See memory usage



4.2.3 The Data Viewer
Click any dataframe to open it in a spreadsheet-like viewer:

Sort by columns
Filter rows
Search for values

[TODO: screenshot of Data Viewer]

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.3 Essential Keyboard Shortcuts



Action
macOS
Windows




Run current line
Cmd+Enter
Ctrl+Enter


Run selection
Cmd+Enter
Ctrl+Enter


Open command palette
Cmd+Shift+P
Ctrl+Shift+P


Toggle terminal
Cmd+| Ctrl+



Quick file open
Cmd+P
Ctrl+P


Save file
Cmd+S
Ctrl+S

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.4 Working with R
Positron detects R automatically. Start an R session by:

Opening an .R file
Clicking “Start R” in the status bar
Running R code in the terminal


4.4.1 Sending Code to Console
Select code and press Cmd+Enter (macOS) or Ctrl+Enter (Windows) to run it.

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.5 Working with Python

4.5.1 Selecting an Interpreter

Open Command Palette (Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P)
Type “Python: Select Interpreter”
Choose your conda environment

NOTE: if you just initalized your conda environment you will need to restart Positron to see it as an option.


4.5.2 Jupyter-style Execution
Python files support # %% cell markers for interactive execution:
# %%
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv("data.csv")

# %%
df.describe()
Run cells with Shift+Enter.

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.6 Recommended Extensions
Positron comes with many extensions pre-installed. Consider adding:

GitLens: Enhanced Git integration
Rainbow CSV: Color-code CSV columns
Quarto: If you use Quarto documents

Install extensions via the Extensions panel (Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+X).

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.7 Project Settings
Create a .vscode/settings.json file for project-specific settings:
{
  "python.defaultInterpreterPath": "~/miniforge3/envs/my-project/bin/python",
  "r.rpath.mac": "/usr/local/bin/R",
  "files.autoSave": "afterDelay"
}

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.8 Tips for Effective Use

Use the Command Palette: Press Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P to access any command
Learn keyboard shortcuts: They significantly speed up your workflow
Split the editor: View multiple files side by side
Use integrated terminal: Keep everything in one window

title: 4  Positron
text:
4.9 Troubleshooting

4.9.1 R not detected

Ensure R is installed and in your PATH
Check Positron settings for R path configuration



4.9.2 Python environment not showing

Activate the conda environment in the terminal first
Use “Python: Select Interpreter” to manually choose it



4.9.3 Slow performance

Close unused tabs
Restart Positron
Check if large data is loaded in memory

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.1 Why Use Environments?
Conda is an environment and package manager that creates isolated spaces for your Python projects. Each environment has its own Python version and packages, preventing conflicts between projects.
Without environments:
With environments:
Each project has exactly what it needs.

title: 5  Conda
text:
Project A needs pandas 1.5
Project B needs pandas 2.0
Both can’t coexist in a single Python installation


project-a-env/
  └── pandas 1.5

project-b-env/
  └── pandas 2.0

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.2 Basic Commands

5.2.1 Create an Environment
# Create with specific Python version
conda create -n my-project python=3.11

# Create with packages included
conda create -n my-project python=3.11 pandas numpy matplotlib


5.2.2 Activate/Deactivate
# Activate (start using the environment)
conda activate my-project

# Deactivate (return to base)
conda deactivate
When activated, your prompt shows the environment name:
(my-project) $


5.2.3 Install Packages
# Install a package
conda install pandas

# Install specific version
conda install pandas=2.0

# Install multiple packages
conda install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn


5.2.4 List Environments
# See all environments
conda env list

# See packages in current environment
conda list


5.2.5 Remove Environment
conda env remove -n my-project

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.3 Environment Files

5.3.1 Export Your Environment
Save your environment to a file so others can recreate it:
conda env export > environment.yml
This creates:
name: my-project
channels:
  - conda-forge
  - defaults
dependencies:
  - python=3.11.5
  - pandas=2.0.3
  - numpy=1.24.3
  - pip:
    - some-pip-package==1.0.0


5.3.2 Recreate from File
conda env create -f environment.yml


5.3.3 Cross-Platform Files
The default export includes platform-specific builds. For cross-platform sharing:
conda env export --from-history > environment.yml
This exports only packages you explicitly installed.

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.4 Best Practices

5.4.1 One Environment Per Project
Create a dedicated environment for each project:
conda create -n genomics-project python=3.11
conda create -n imaging-analysis python=3.10


5.4.2 Name Environments Meaningfully
Use descriptive names:
# Good
conda create -n tihkal-analysis python=3.11

# Less helpful
conda create -n env1 python=3.11


5.4.3 Pin Major Versions
Specify Python version when creating:
conda create -n my-project python=3.11  # Not just "python"


5.4.4 Update Regularly (But Carefully)
# Update all packages
conda update --all

# Update specific package
conda update pandas
Test after updating to ensure nothing breaks.

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.5 Conda vs pip
Both install Python packages. General rule:

Use conda first for scientific packages (pandas, numpy, scipy)
Use pip for packages not available in conda

# Prefer
conda install pandas

# If not available in conda
pip install some-other-package






WarningMixing conda and pip



When using both, install conda packages first, then pip packages. This avoids dependency conflicts.

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.6 Channels
Channels are package repositories. The main ones:

conda-forge: Community-maintained, most packages
defaults: Anaconda’s default channel

We use Miniforge which defaults to conda-forge:
# Explicitly specify channel if needed
conda install -c conda-forge package-name

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.7 Troubleshooting

5.7.1 “Solving environment” takes forever
This happens with complex dependency trees. Try:
# Use mamba (faster solver)
conda install mamba
mamba install package-name


5.7.2 Package not found

Check spelling
Try conda-forge channel explicitly
Fall back to pip



5.7.3 Environment corrupted
Remove and recreate:
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n my-project
conda env create -f environment.yml

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.8 Integration with Positron

Activate your environment in the terminal
In Positron, open Command Palette (Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P)
Type “Python: Select Interpreter”
Choose the environment

The environment’s Python will be used for running scripts and notebooks.

title: 5  Conda
text:
5.9 Quick Reference



Task
Command




Create environment
conda create -n NAME python=3.11


Activate
conda activate NAME


Deactivate
conda deactivate


Install package
conda install PACKAGE


Export environment
conda env export > environment.yml


Create from file
conda env create -f environment.yml


List environments
conda env list


Remove environment
conda env remove -n NAME

title: 6  renv
text:
6.1 Why renv?
renv is R’s package management system. Like conda for Python, it creates isolated package libraries for each project, ensuring reproducibility.
Without renv: - All projects share one R package library - Updating a package for one project might break another - Hard to know which packages a project needs
With renv: - Each project has its own package library - Package versions are locked in renv.lock - Anyone can recreate your exact environment

title: 6  renv
text:
6.2 Getting Started

6.2.1 Initialize renv
In a new or existing R project:
# Install renv if needed
install.packages("renv")

# Initialize renv for this project
renv::init()
This creates: - renv/ — Local package library - renv.lock — Lockfile recording package versions - .Rprofile — Activates renv when R starts


6.2.2 The Workflow

Install packages as normal with install.packages()
Snapshot to record what you installed: renv::snapshot()
Share your project (including renv.lock)
Restore on another machine: renv::restore()

title: 6  renv
text:
6.3 Essential Commands

6.3.1 Installing Packages
# Install from CRAN
install.packages("ggplot2")

# Install from GitHub
renv::install("tidyverse/ggplot2")

# Install specific version
renv::install("ggplot2@3.4.0")


6.3.2 Snapshot
After installing packages, save the state:
renv::snapshot()
This updates renv.lock with current package versions.


6.3.3 Restore
When you clone a project or switch machines:
renv::restore()
This installs all packages recorded in renv.lock.


6.3.4 Status
Check if your library matches the lockfile:
renv::status()
Outputs tell you if packages are: - Missing from the library - Not recorded in the lockfile - Different versions than the lockfile

title: 6  renv
6  renv
text:
6.5 What to Commit to Git
Include: - renv.lock — Package versions - renv/activate.R — Activation script - .Rprofile — Auto-activation
Exclude (in .gitignore): - renv/library/ — Actual packages (too large) - renv/staging/ — Temporary files

title: 6  renv
text:
6.6 Updating Packages

6.6.1 Update All
renv::update()
renv::snapshot()  # Don't forget to snapshot!


6.6.2 Update Specific Package
renv::update("ggplot2")
renv::snapshot()


6.6.3 Revert an Update
If something breaks, restore the previous state:
renv::restore()

title: 6  renv
text:
6.7 Common Issues

6.7.1 “The project is out-of-sync”
This means packages in your library don’t match renv.lock:
# See what's different
renv::status()

# Sync library to lockfile
renv::restore()

# Or update lockfile to match library
renv::snapshot()


6.7.2 Package Installation Fails
Try:
# Clear cache and reinstall
renv::install("package-name", rebuild = TRUE)


6.7.3 Starting Fresh
If things are really broken:
# Remove renv from project
renv::deactivate()
unlink("renv", recursive = TRUE)
file.remove("renv.lock")

# Reinitialize
renv::init()

title: 6  renv
text:
6.8 Working with Bioconductor
For bioinformatics packages:
# Set up Bioconductor
renv::install("BiocManager")
BiocManager::install("DESeq2")
renv::snapshot()
renv automatically detects Bioconductor packages.

title: 6  renv
text:
6.9 Integration with Positron
renv works automatically with Positron:

Open a project with renv
R automatically activates renv (via .Rprofile)
Install packages as normal
Run renv::snapshot() to save

The R console should show:
- Project '/path/to/project' loaded. [renv 1.0.0]

title: 6  renv
text:
6.10 Best Practices

6.10.1 Snapshot Regularly
After installing or updating packages:
renv::snapshot()
git add renv.lock
git commit -m "Update package dependencies"


6.10.2 Check Status Before Committing
renv::status()
Ensure the lockfile reflects your actual packages.


6.10.3 Document Special Packages
If packages need special installation (GitHub, local, etc.), document it:
# Install custom packages:
# renv::install("github-user/custom-package")

title: 6  renv
text:
6.11 Quick Reference



Task
Command




Initialize
renv::init()


Install package
install.packages("pkg")


Snapshot
renv::snapshot()


Restore
renv::restore()


Check status
renv::status()


Update all
renv::update()


Update one
renv::update("pkg")

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.1 Why Version Control?
Git tracks changes to your code over time. GitHub hosts your Git repositories online for backup and collaboration.
Without version control:
With Git: - One file, complete history - See what changed, when, and why - Revert mistakes - Collaborate without overwriting each other

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
analysis_v1.R
analysis_v2.R
analysis_v2_final.R
analysis_v2_final_FINAL.R
analysis_v2_final_FINAL_fixed.R

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.2 Git Basics

7.2.1 Key Concepts

Repository (repo): A project folder tracked by Git
Commit: A snapshot of your project at a point in time
Stage: Mark files to include in the next commit
Branch: A parallel version of your project
Remote: A copy of your repo on another server (like GitHub)



7.2.2 The Basic Workflow
# 1. Make changes to files

# 2. See what changed
git status

# 3. Stage changes
git add filename.R
# Or stage everything:
git add .

# 4. Commit with a message
git commit -m "Add analysis script"


7.2.3 Viewing History
# See commit history
git log

# See compact history
git log --oneline

# See what changed in a commit
git show abc123

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.3 Essential Commands

7.3.1 Starting a Repo
# Initialize new repo
git init

# Clone existing repo
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git


7.3.2 Daily Work
# Check status
git status

# See changes
git diff

# Stage files
git add file.R
git add .  # All files

# Commit
git commit -m "Your message"

# Push to GitHub
git push


7.3.3 Undoing Things
# Unstage a file
git reset HEAD file.R

# Discard changes to a file
git checkout -- file.R

# Undo last commit (keep changes)
git reset --soft HEAD~1

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.4 Writing Good Commit Messages
Bad: - “update” - “fix” - “changes”
Good: - “Add function to normalize expression data” - “Fix off-by-one error in loop index” - “Update README with installation instructions”
Format: - Short summary (50 chars or less) - Blank line - Detailed description if needed

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.5 Branching
Branches let you work on features without affecting the main code.
# Create and switch to new branch
git checkout -b feature-name

# Work, commit, etc...

# Switch back to main
git checkout main

# Merge feature into main
git merge feature-name

7.5.1 When to Branch

Adding a new feature
Fixing a bug
Experimenting

Keep main stable. Do work in branches.

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.6 GitHub
GitHub hosts your repositories online, enabling:

Backup of your code
Collaboration with others
Issue tracking
Pull requests for code review


7.6.1 Connecting to GitHub
# Add remote
git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git

# Push (first time)
git push -u origin main

# Push (after first time)
git push


7.6.2 Pull Changes
If someone else pushed changes:
git pull


7.6.3 Cloning a Repo
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git
cd repo

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.7 Pull Requests
Pull requests (PRs) let you propose changes and get feedback.

Create a branch
Make changes and push
Open PR on GitHub
Get review/feedback
Merge when approved

This is standard for collaboration, even on solo projects (to review your own work).

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.8 .gitignore
List files Git should ignore:
# Data files (too large)
data/raw/
*.csv

# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/

# Python
__pycache__/
*.pyc

# Secrets
.env
credentials.json

# OS files
.DS_Store
Create .gitignore before your first commit.

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.9 Common Scenarios

7.9.1 “I committed but haven’t pushed”
You can still modify:
# Amend the last commit
git commit --amend -m "New message"

# Add forgotten file to last commit
git add forgotten-file.R
git commit --amend --no-edit


7.9.2 “I want to see an old version”
# View old version of file
git show abc123:path/to/file.R

# Temporarily go back to old commit
git checkout abc123
git checkout main  # Return to present


7.9.3 “I have merge conflicts”
When the same lines changed in both branches:

Open the conflicted file
Look for conflict markers:
<<<<<<< HEAD
your changes
=======
their changes
>>>>>>> branch-name
Edit to resolve (keep what you want)
Remove the markers
Stage and commit

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.10 Best Practices

7.10.1 Commit Often
Small, focused commits are easier to understand and revert.


7.10.2 Pull Before Push
git pull
git push
Avoid conflicts by syncing first.


7.10.3 Don’t Commit Secrets
Never commit passwords, API keys, or credentials. Use .gitignore.


7.10.4 Don’t Commit Large Data
Git struggles with large files. Keep data separate or use Git LFS.

title: 7  Git & GitHub
text:
7.11 Quick Reference



Task
Command




Initialize repo
git init


Clone repo
git clone URL


Check status
git status


Stage file
git add FILE


Stage all
git add .


Commit
git commit -m "message"


Push
git push


Pull
git pull


View log
git log --oneline


Create branch
git checkout -b NAME


Switch branch
git checkout NAME


Merge branch
git merge NAME

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.1 What Claude Code Can Do
Claude Code is an AI assistant that runs in your terminal and helps you write, debug, and understand code. Unlike web-based AI tools, Claude Code works directly with your files and can execute commands.

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
Write code — Generate scripts, functions, and analyses
Edit files — Modify existing code based on your instructions
Run commands — Execute shell commands and see output
Search codebases — Find files and patterns across projects
Explain code — Help you understand complex code
Debug — Identify and fix errors

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.2 Installation
See Installation for setup instructions.

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.3 Basic Usage

8.3.1 Starting a Session
In your project directory:
claude
This opens an interactive session where you can type requests.


8.3.2 Example Prompts
Writing code: > “Create a Python script that loads data.csv and plots a histogram of the ‘value’ column”
Editing files: > “In analysis.R, add a log transformation step after loading the data”
Running commands: > “Run the tests and show me any failures”
Understanding code: > “Explain what the normalize_counts function does”


8.3.3 Exiting
Type /exit or press Ctrl+C to end the session.

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.4 Configuring Claude Code

8.4.1 The CLAUDE.md File
Claude Code reads instructions from CLAUDE.md files. This is how you teach it about your project.
Global instructions go in ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md — these apply to all projects.
Project-specific instructions go in <project>/.claude/CLAUDE.md — these apply only to that project.


8.4.2 What to Put in Project CLAUDE.md
Create .claude/CLAUDE.md in your project root:
# Project: My Analysis

## Overview
This project analyzes gene expression data from [experiment description].

## Environment
- Python: conda activate my-analysis-env
- R: Uses renv (auto-activates)

## Key Files
- `data/raw/` — Original data files (do not modify)
- `scripts/` — Analysis scripts
- `output/` — Results and figures

## Workflows
- Run full analysis: `quarto render analysis.qmd`
- Run tests: `pytest tests/`

## Conventions
- Use tidyverse style for R
- Functions should have docstrings
- Commit after completing each analysis step
Claude Code reads this at the start of each session, giving it context about your project.


8.4.3 Skills
Skills are reusable instructions for specific tasks. They live in ~/.claude/skills/ and load automatically when relevant.
Example skill structure:
~/.claude/skills/
├── data-handling/
│   └── SKILL.md
├── r-plotting-style/
│   └── SKILL.md
└── git-conventions/
    └── SKILL.md
Skills are triggered by keywords in your requests. For example, a “data-handling” skill might activate when you ask Claude to write data analysis code.

8.4.3.1 Example: Data Handling Skill
A data handling skill might instruct Claude to:

Show data summaries after major transformations
Annotate analytical decisions with comments
Validate joins and report row counts
Ask before making important analytical choices

# Data Handling Best Practices

## Show Data at Key Steps

Include `glimpse()` or summaries whenever datasets are created or altered:

\```r
data <- read_csv("data.csv")
cat("Loaded", nrow(data), "rows,", ncol(data), "columns\n")
glimpse(data)
\```

## Annotate Analytical Decisions

Document the "why" directly in code comments:

\```r
# Normalize by library size using TMM (Robinson & Oshlack 2010)
# TMM chosen over RLE because of high proportion of zeros
norm_factors <- calcNormFactors(dge, method = "TMM")
\```


8.4.3.2 Example: Git Conventions Skill
A git skill might instruct Claude to:

Include co-author attribution in commits
Check status before committing
Prompt you about commits at appropriate times

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.5 Working Effectively with Claude Code

8.5.1 Be Specific
Vague: > “Make the plot better”
Specific: > “In figure1.R, change the plot colors to a colorblind-friendly palette and increase the axis label font size to 14pt”


8.5.2 Provide Context
Without context: > “Fix the error”
With context: > “The script throws ‘object not found’ on line 45. I think it’s because the data loading step failed.”


8.5.3 Ask for Explanations
Don’t just accept code — understand it:

“Explain why you chose that normalization method”


“What are the trade-offs of this approach?”



8.5.4 Review Before Accepting
Claude Code shows you changes before applying them. Review:

Does the code do what you asked?
Are there any obvious errors?
Does it follow your project conventions?

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.6 Integration with Other Tools

8.6.1 With Git
Claude Code can commit changes for you:

“Commit these changes with a descriptive message”

It will show you the diff and proposed message before committing.


8.6.2 With Conda
For Python work, Claude Code can activate your environment:
source ~/miniforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh && conda activate my-env && python script.py
Document your conda environment in .claude/CLAUDE.md so Claude knows which one to use.


8.6.3 With renv
R environments activate automatically via .Rprofile. Just tell Claude Code your project uses renv and it will respect package versions.


8.6.4 With Quarto
Claude Code can render Quarto documents:

“Render analysis.qmd and show me any errors”

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.7 Common Workflows

8.7.1 Starting a New Analysis

Open Claude Code in your project
Describe what you want to analyze
Let it scaffold the initial structure
Review and refine iteratively

Example: > “I have RNA-seq count data in data/counts.csv. Help me set up a differential expression analysis using DESeq2. Start by creating a script that loads the data and does quality control.”


8.7.2 Debugging

Describe the error
Show the relevant code or file
Ask for diagnosis and fix

Example: > “Running analysis.R gives this error: [paste error]. The relevant code is in the normalize_data function. What’s wrong?”


8.7.3 Code Review

“Review scripts/analysis.R. Are there any bugs, style issues, or ways to improve it?”



8.7.4 Documentation

“Add comments explaining the key steps in analysis.R”

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.8 Tips for Success

8.8.1 Start Small
Don’t ask Claude to build an entire analysis at once. Build incrementally:

Load and inspect data
Clean and transform
Analyze
Visualize
Document



8.8.2 Trust but Verify
Claude Code is helpful but not infallible:

Review generated code before running
Test with small datasets first
Check that results make scientific sense



8.8.3 Save Your Prompts
If you find prompts that work well, save them:

In your CLAUDE.md file
As skills for reuse
In project documentation

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.9 Troubleshooting

8.9.1 “Command not found” for conda
Claude Code runs in a non-interactive shell. Source conda explicitly:
source ~/miniforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh && conda activate ENV && command


8.9.2 Claude doesn’t know about my project
Check that your .claude/CLAUDE.md exists and contains relevant information. Claude reads this at session start.


8.9.3 Responses are too generic
Provide more context:

Describe your data
Explain your goals
Point to relevant files
Share error messages in full

title: 8  Claude Code
text:
8.10 Quick Reference



Task
Example Prompt




Write code
“Create a script that…”


Edit file
“In file.R, change X to Y”


Run command
“Run pytest and show failures”


Explain code
“Explain the normalize function”


Debug
“This error occurs: [error]. Why?”


Commit
“Commit with message describing changes”

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
9.1 The Standard Structure
This chapter walks through setting up a new analysis project from scratch, using all the tools together.
Every analysis project should have:
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
project-name/
├── .claude/
│   └── CLAUDE.md         # Claude Code instructions
├── .git/                  # Git repository
├── .gitignore            # Files to exclude from Git
├── data/
│   ├── raw/              # Original data (never modify)
│   └── processed/        # Cleaned/transformed data
├── scripts/              # Analysis scripts
├── output/               # Results, figures, tables
├── environment.yml       # Conda environment (Python)
├── renv.lock            # R package versions
└── README.md            # Project description
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
9.2 Step-by-Step Setup

9.2.1 1. Create the Project Directory
mkdir my-analysis
cd my-analysis


9.2.2 2. Initialize Git
git init
Create .gitignore:
# Data (large files)
data/raw/
*.csv
*.tsv
*.xlsx

# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/
renv/library/
renv/staging/

# Python
__pycache__/
*.pyc
.venv/

# Output (regenerated from code)
output/

# OS
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db

# IDE
.vscode/
.positron/

# Secrets
.env


9.2.3 3. Create Directory Structure
mkdir -p data/raw data/processed scripts output .claude


9.2.4 4. Set Up Python Environment (if using Python)
conda create -n my-analysis python=3.11 -y
conda activate my-analysis
conda install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn -y
conda env export > environment.yml


9.2.5 5. Set Up R with renv (if using R)
In R:
renv::init()
install.packages(c("tidyverse", "here"))
renv::snapshot()


9.2.6 6. Create Project CLAUDE.md
Create .claude/CLAUDE.md:
# Project: My Analysis

## Overview
[Brief description of what this project does]

## Environment
- Python: `conda activate my-analysis`
- R: Uses renv (auto-activates)

## Key Directories
- `data/raw/` — Original data (read-only)
- `data/processed/` — Cleaned data
- `scripts/` — Analysis code
- `output/` — Results and figures

## Workflows
[How to run the analysis]

## Data
[Description of data files and their contents]


9.2.7 7. Create README
Create README.md:
# My Analysis

## Overview
[What this project does]

## Setup

### Python
conda env create -f environment.yml
conda activate my-analysis

### R
# renv will auto-activate; run renv::restore() if needed

## Running the Analysis
[Instructions]

## Data
[Data sources and descriptions]


9.2.8 8. First Commit
git add .
git commit -m "Initial project setup"


9.2.9 9. Push to GitHub
gh repo create my-analysis --private --source=. --push
Or manually:

Create repo on GitHub
git remote add origin https://github.com/USERNAME/my-analysis.git
git push -u origin main
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
9.3 Adding Data

9.3.1 Raw Data
Put original data files in data/raw/. Never modify these files — treat them as read-only.
If data files are large, don’t commit them to Git. Add to .gitignore:
data/raw/*.csv
Instead, document where to obtain the data in your README.


9.3.2 Processing Data
Scripts that clean or transform data should:

Read from data/raw/
Write to data/processed/
Include documentation of what transformations were applied

# scripts/01_clean_data.R

library(tidyverse)
library(here)

# Load raw data
raw <- read_csv(here("data/raw/experiment_data.csv"))
cat("Loaded", nrow(raw), "rows\n")

# Clean: remove rows with missing values
clean <- raw %>%
  filter(!is.na(value)) %>%
  filter(quality > 0.8)
cat("After cleaning:", nrow(clean), "rows\n")

# Save
write_csv(clean, here("data/processed/clean_data.csv"))
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
9.4 Organizing Scripts
Name scripts with numbers to indicate order:
scripts/
├── 01_clean_data.R
├── 02_exploratory_analysis.R
├── 03_statistical_analysis.R
└── 04_generate_figures.R
Or organize by function:
scripts/
├── preprocessing/
│   ├── clean_data.R
│   └── normalize.R
├── analysis/
│   ├── differential_expression.R
│   └── pathway_analysis.R
└── figures/
    ├── figure1.R
    └── figure2.R
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
9.5 Using Claude Code
With your .claude/CLAUDE.md in place, start Claude Code:
claude
Example workflow:

“I have RNA-seq counts in data/raw/counts.csv. Create a script to load it, do basic QC, and save a cleaned version.”

Review the generated code, then:

“Commit this with an appropriate message”
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project
text:
9.6 Checklist
Before starting analysis:

Git initialized
.gitignore in place
Directory structure created
Conda environment created and exported
renv initialized (if using R)
.claude/CLAUDE.md written
README drafted
First commit made
Pushed to GitHub
crumbs: 9  Starting a New Analysis Project

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.1 Sharing a Project
This chapter covers how to work on projects with collaborators using Git and GitHub.

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.1.1 Giving Access
On GitHub:

Go to repository Settings → Collaborators
Click Add people
Enter collaborator’s GitHub username or email
They’ll receive an invitation



10.1.2 Collaborator Setup
Your collaborator clones the repo:
git clone https://github.com/USERNAME/project-name.git
cd project-name
Then sets up environments:
# Python
conda env create -f environment.yml
conda activate project-name

# R (in R console)
renv::restore()

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.2 The Collaboration Workflow

10.2.1 Before Starting Work
Always pull the latest changes:
git pull
Check for environment updates:
# Python - check if environment.yml changed
conda env update -f environment.yml

# R - check renv status
# renv::status()
# renv::restore()


10.2.2 Making Changes

Pull latest changes
Do your work
Stage and commit
Push

git pull
# ... make changes ...
git add .
git commit -m "Add analysis for condition B"
git push


10.2.3 When Collaborators Push
If someone pushed while you were working:
git pull
# May need to resolve conflicts (see below)
git push

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.3 Branching Workflow
For larger changes, use branches:

10.3.1 Create a Branch
git checkout -b my-feature


10.3.2 Work on the Branch
# Make changes, commit as usual
git add .
git commit -m "Add new analysis"


10.3.3 Push the Branch
git push -u origin my-feature


10.3.4 Create a Pull Request

Go to the repository on GitHub
Click Compare & pull request
Add description of changes
Request review from collaborator
Merge when approved



10.3.5 After Merging
git checkout main
git pull
git branch -d my-feature  # Delete local branch

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.4 Handling Merge Conflicts
Conflicts happen when two people change the same lines.

10.4.1 Recognizing a Conflict
git pull
# CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.R
# Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit.


10.4.2 Resolving Conflicts
Open the conflicted file. You’ll see markers:
<<<<<<< HEAD
# Your version
result <- calculate_mean(data)
=======
# Their version
result <- calculate_median(data)
>>>>>>> origin/main
Edit to keep what you want:
# Keep both approaches, or choose one
result_mean <- calculate_mean(data)
result_median <- calculate_median(data)
Remove the conflict markers, then:
git add analysis.R
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict in analysis.R"
git push

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.5 Environment Synchronization

10.5.1 When You Add Packages
Python:
conda install new-package
conda env export > environment.yml
git add environment.yml
git commit -m "Add new-package to environment"
git push
R:
install.packages("new-package")
renv::snapshot()
git add renv.lock
git commit -m "Add new-package to renv"
git push


10.5.2 When Collaborator Adds Packages
After pulling:
Python:
conda env update -f environment.yml
R:
renv::restore()

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.6 Best Practices

10.6.1 Communicate

Tell collaborators what you’re working on
Avoid working on the same files simultaneously
Use issues to track tasks



10.6.2 Commit Often
Small, frequent commits are easier to merge than large changes.


10.6.3 Pull Before Push
git pull
git push
This catches conflicts early.


10.6.4 Use .gitignore
Ensure everyone has the same .gitignore to avoid committing:

Large data files
Personal IDE settings
System files



10.6.5 Document Changes
Update README and documentation when you change:

How to run the analysis
Environment dependencies
Data requirements

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.7 Working with GitHub Issues

10.7.1 Creating Issues
Use issues to track:

Bugs to fix
Features to add
Questions to resolve

Click New Issue on GitHub and describe the task.


10.7.2 Referencing Issues in Commits
Link commits to issues:
git commit -m "Fix normalization bug (closes #12)"
This automatically closes the issue when merged.

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.8 Forking (For External Collaborators)
If someone isn’t a direct collaborator:

They fork the repo (creates their copy)
They make changes in their fork
They open a pull request to your repo
You review and merge

This is common for open-source contributions.

title: 10  Collaborating with Others
text:
10.9 Checklist for Collaboration
Starting a collaborative project:

Repository on GitHub with collaborators added
Clear README with setup instructions
.gitignore preventing large/personal files
environment.yml (Python) and renv.lock (R) committed
Agreed workflow (branches vs direct commits)
Communication channel established

Daily workflow:

Pull before starting work
Update environments if needed
Commit small, focused changes
Push when done
Communicate about what you changed

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.1 Why Reproducibility Matters
Reproducibility means others (including future you) can run your analysis and get the same results. This chapter covers practices that ensure reproducibility.

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
Verification: Others can check your work
Building on work: You or others can extend the analysis
Debugging: Easier to find and fix problems
Publication: Increasingly required by journals
Future you: Six months from now, you’ll thank yourself

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.2 The Three Pillars

11.2.1 1. Version Control (Git)
Track every change to your code:

What changed
When it changed
Why it changed

With Git, you can always return to a working state.


11.2.2 2. Environment Management (Conda + renv)
Lock down exact package versions:
# environment.yml
dependencies:
  - python=3.11.5
  - pandas=2.0.3
  - numpy=1.24.3
// renv.lock
"ggplot2": {
  "Version": "3.4.2"
}
Different package versions can give different results.


11.2.3 3. Documentation
Explain:

How to set up the environment
How to run the analysis
What the data looks like
What decisions you made and why

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.3 Reproducibility Checklist

11.3.1 Environment

All dependencies listed in environment.yml (Python) or renv.lock (R)
Specific versions pinned, not just package names
Instructions for environment setup in README



11.3.2 Data

Raw data preserved unchanged
Data processing steps documented and scripted
Data sources documented
If data can’t be shared, describe format and structure



11.3.3 Code

Analysis runs from start to finish without manual intervention
File paths are relative, not absolute
No hardcoded paths like /Users/myname/...
Random seeds set for stochastic processes
Intermediate results can be regenerated from code



11.3.4 Documentation

README explains setup and execution
Analysis steps documented in code comments or notebooks
Key decisions annotated with rationale

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.4 Using Relative Paths
Bad — hardcoded absolute paths:
data <- read_csv("/Users/jm284/projects/analysis/data/raw/data.csv")
Good — relative paths with here:
library(here)
data <- read_csv(here("data/raw/data.csv"))
Python — use pathlib:
from pathlib import Path

data_dir = Path(__file__).parent.parent / "data" / "raw"
data = pd.read_csv(data_dir / "data.csv")
The here package (R) and pathlib (Python) find paths relative to the project root, regardless of where scripts are run from.

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.5 Setting Random Seeds
Many analyses involve randomness (bootstrapping, sampling, train/test splits). Set seeds for reproducibility:
R:
set.seed(42)
result <- sample(data, 100)
Python:
import random
import numpy as np

random.seed(42)
np.random.seed(42)
result = np.random.choice(data, 100)
Document why you chose that seed (or just pick a number consistently).

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.6 Documenting Data
In your README or a separate DATA.md:
# Data Description

## Raw Data

### data/raw/counts.csv
- Source: GEO accession GSE12345
- Downloaded: 2024-01-15
- Format: CSV, 20,000 genes × 12 samples
- Columns: gene_id, sample1, sample2, ...

### data/raw/metadata.csv
- Source: Provided by collaborator
- Format: CSV, 12 rows
- Columns: sample_id, condition, batch, replicate

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.7 Running the Full Analysis
Create a master script or Makefile that runs everything:
Shell script (run_analysis.sh):
#!/bin/bash
set -e  # Exit on error

echo "Setting up environment..."
conda activate my-analysis

echo "Step 1: Cleaning data..."
Rscript scripts/01_clean_data.R

echo "Step 2: Analysis..."
python scripts/02_analyze.py

echo "Step 3: Figures..."
Rscript scripts/03_figures.R

echo "Done!"
Quarto (analysis.qmd):
A Quarto document that runs all code chunks in order is inherently reproducible — rendering the document runs the full analysis.
Make (Makefile):
all: output/figures/figure1.pdf output/results.csv

output/figures/figure1.pdf: scripts/03_figures.R data/processed/clean.csv
    Rscript scripts/03_figures.R

data/processed/clean.csv: scripts/01_clean_data.R data/raw/data.csv
    Rscript scripts/01_clean_data.R

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.8 Testing Reproducibility

11.8.1 Fresh Environment Test

Clone your repo to a new location
Create environment from scratch
Run the full analysis
Compare results

# In a temporary directory
git clone https://github.com/user/project.git test-project
cd test-project
conda env create -f environment.yml
conda activate project-name
./run_analysis.sh


11.8.2 Docker (Advanced)
For maximum reproducibility, package everything in a Docker container:
FROM rocker/tidyverse:4.3.1

COPY . /analysis
WORKDIR /analysis

RUN R -e "renv::restore()"

CMD ["Rscript", "run_all.R"]
This captures:

Operating system
R version
All packages

title: 11  Reproducible Analysis
text:
11.9 Common Reproducibility Problems

11.9.1 “It works on my machine”
Cause: Different package versions, OS differences, or missing dependencies.
Solution: Use conda/renv, test in fresh environment.


11.9.2 Missing files
Cause: Data files not included or paths are wrong.
Solution: Document data sources, use relative paths.


11.9.3 Different results each run
Cause: Unseeded random number generation.
Solution: Set random seeds.


11.9.4 Manual steps
Cause: Analysis requires clicking buttons or manual edits.
Solution: Script everything. If you must have manual steps, document them precisely.

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.1 Conda
This chapter covers frequently asked questions and common problems.

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.1.1 “command not found: conda”
macOS/Linux: Conda isn’t initialized in this shell session.
source ~/miniforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh
# Or for miniconda:
source ~/miniconda3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh
Add this to your ~/.zshrc or ~/.bashrc to make it permanent.
Windows: Open “Anaconda Prompt” or “Miniforge Prompt” instead of regular Command Prompt.


12.1.2 “Solving environment” is very slow
Conda’s dependency resolver can be slow with complex environments.
Solutions:

Use mamba (faster drop-in replacement):
conda install mamba -n base
mamba install package-name
Create minimal environments:
conda create -n project python=3.11 pandas numpy
# Instead of installing everything at once
Use conda-forge channel consistently:
conda config --add channels conda-forge
conda config --set channel_priority strict



12.1.3 Environment not activating in Positron

Open Positron’s integrated terminal
Manually activate: conda activate my-env
Use Command Palette: “Python: Select Interpreter” → choose the environment



12.1.4 Recreating a broken environment
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n broken-env
conda env create -f environment.yml

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.2 renv

12.2.1 “The project is out-of-sync”
This warning means packages in your library don’t match renv.lock.
To see what’s different:
renv::status()
To sync library to lockfile (recommended):
renv::restore()
To update lockfile to match library:
renv::snapshot()


12.2.2 Package installation fails
Try clearing the cache and rebuilding:
renv::install("package-name", rebuild = TRUE)
For persistent issues:
# Check for system dependencies
renv::diagnostics()

# Install from a different repository
renv::install("package-name", repos = "https://cloud.r-project.org")


12.2.3 Starting fresh with renv
renv::deactivate()
rm -rf renv renv.lock .Rprofile
renv::init()

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.3 Git

12.3.1 “Updates were rejected because the remote contains work…”
Someone pushed while you were working.
git pull
# Resolve any conflicts if needed
git push


12.3.2 Accidentally committed large files
Remove from history (if not yet pushed):
git reset --soft HEAD~1
# Edit .gitignore to exclude the file
git add .gitignore
git commit -m "Fix gitignore"
If already pushed, use BFG or git-filter-branch (more complex).


12.3.3 Undo the last commit (keep changes)
git reset --soft HEAD~1


12.3.4 See what changed in a file
git log -p filename.R


12.3.5 Discard all uncommitted changes
git checkout -- .
# Or for all files including untracked:
git clean -fd
⚠️ This permanently deletes uncommitted work!

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.4 Claude Code

12.4.1 “Command not found” for conda in Claude Code
Claude Code runs in a non-interactive shell. Always source conda first:
source ~/miniforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh && conda activate my-env && python script.py
Document this pattern in your .claude/CLAUDE.md.


12.4.2 Claude doesn’t understand my project
Ensure .claude/CLAUDE.md exists and contains:

Project overview
Environment setup commands
Key file locations
Common workflows



12.4.3 Responses are generic or unhelpful
Provide more context:

Show the specific file or code
Explain what you’re trying to accomplish
Share error messages in full

Instead of: “Fix the bug”
Try: “In analysis.R line 45, I get ‘object x not found’. Here’s the relevant code: [paste code]. The data is loaded from data/raw/data.csv.”

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.5 Positron

12.5.1 R not detected

Check R is installed: R --version in terminal
In Positron settings, search for “R Path” and set it explicitly
Restart Positron



12.5.2 Python interpreter not showing

Activate conda environment in terminal
Command Palette → “Python: Select Interpreter”
Click “Enter interpreter path” and navigate to the environment’s Python



12.5.3 Slow or unresponsive

Close unused tabs
Restart Positron
Check if large objects are in memory (clear R/Python session)
Check system memory usage

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.6 Quarto

12.6.1 “quarto: command not found”
macOS:
brew install quarto
# Or use full path:
/usr/local/bin/quarto render document.qmd
Windows: Ensure Quarto installer added it to PATH. Restart terminal.


12.6.2 Render fails with R errors

Run the R code chunks manually to find the error
Check that all packages are installed
Ensure working directory is correct (use here package)



12.6.3 Render fails with Python errors

Ensure correct conda environment is active
Check Python interpreter in document YAML:
jupyter: python3

title: 12  Common Tasks & Troubleshooting
text:
12.7 General Workflow

12.7.1 How do I start working on a project?
cd project-directory
conda activate project-env  # if Python
positron .
# R activates renv automatically via .Rprofile


12.7.2 How do I end a work session?
git status                    # See what changed
git add .                     # Stage changes
git commit -m "Description"   # Commit
git push                      # Push to GitHub


12.7.3 How do I update all packages?
Python:
conda update --all
conda env export > environment.yml
git add environment.yml && git commit -m "Update packages"
R:
renv::update()
renv::snapshot()
git add renv.lock && git commit -m "Update R packages"


12.7.4 How do I share my project?

Ensure environment.yml and renv.lock are up to date
Write clear README with setup instructions
Push to GitHub
Share the repository URL

The collaborator then:
git clone https://github.com/user/project.git
cd project
conda env create -f environment.yml
# In R: renv::restore()
